title: Helper Disc Supports Rafting Decrease Warping Corners

description.text: I created these different sized (S,M,L,XL) helper discs to keep corners from curling and warping off the heated build plate during larger builds. This is my first upload and I hope it helps you complete better builds. Thank you Thingiverse family!
Add the correct size to your corner or multiple pieces that should be kept in place during a build and use an xacto knife to cut off the thin circle from your part.

description.text:
This is an ergonomic handle replacement for 5 gallon buckets.

I replaced the handles on a bunch of buckets around my house. The first one I replaced because the original handle had crumbled away. Some other buckets handles I replaced were still intact, but I replaced them anyways since I find my version much more comfortable. To remove old handles I used a pair of tin snips.

Of the 4 buckets I put handles on, I found the steel wire handle to be in the range of 3.5 to 3.75mm diameter. This part is designed to snap onto these size wire with some force, and not fall off.

If you print one please click "I Made One" and post a pic. I love to see when people use my designs.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports needed for the Extruder Bracket.

description.text:
This is my atempt to realize a bowden carrier with an E3D v6 Extruder for the Anet A8.
Most of the common parts can be used like Fans and bearings.

Additional is needed:
12x M3x16 Screws (6 for the Carrier, 2 for the Extruder Bracket, 4 for the main fan)
6x M3x20 Screws for the lower carrier
2x M3x28 Screws for the radial fan
14x M3 Nuts
4x LM8UU bearings or Igus bearings (I chose the LM8UU, had some stick slip issues with the Igus bearings)

I use the radial duct:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620630

It is designed for the use of 20 teeth pulleys and the referring belt width and the Tronxy P802 auto level sensor (inductive).

V2 has some improvements at the belt guide through the plates and the plate for the radial fan is repositioned for the use of the ring duct without extra spacers.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.12

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with PETG
235°C Extruder
70°C Bed

description.text:
This is the second revision of my E3D dual print-head mount for Vertex K8400 published here. The old design had the following issues:

  • the lower ends of left and right holders were too close to the heat-blocks and could melt
  • as the result of printing process imperfections there were several gaps in between things causing ducts to leak air
  • air duct openings were not aligned with the nozzles
  • there was insufficient airflow/cooling towards bearings located under the print-head
  • the wires coming from heaters and thermistors were hanging around X rod and it was not easy to fish them into the long channels of the main thing
  • the fan was fixed in the position with sliding-in piece rather than screws
  • air was hitting heat-blocks not allowing them to reach temperatures above 223 degrees
  • while LEDs looked as a cool feature, they were not very practical due to ever-changing amount of light that hits Raspberry Pi camera. Having stationary LED strips along the edges of the printer is a better option.
  • overall appearance/design had issues (at least in my opinion)

New design addresses everything from the above list. In addition, it allows to gain few additional millimeters of printing space along X and Y axis (details below). 15 Ohm resistor used in the 1st design now allows to reach temperatures up to 240 degrees. Replacing it with 33 Ohm 1Watt resistor will reduce airflow and the noise produced by the fan and will allow to heat up-to 270 degrees, which is the maximum nozzle operating temperature.

Required parts

  • One or two E3D v6 HotEnd Full Kit - 1.75mm Universal (with Bowden add-on) (12v). You can purchase them from here. Buy the original; Chinese replica will not fit into this design.
  • Heater cartridge(s) - one per print head. You MUST reuse the original ones from K8400. Do not install the cartridges that came with E3D as they are for 12V, while the printer supplies 15V DC.
  • One 33 Ohm 1W resistor
  • One 40mm x 40mm x 20mm 12V high speed fan
  • Four M4 x 16mm hex socket cup screws
  • Four countersunk screws M3 x 50mm. They are part of the original hot-end mount and can be re-used (I used M3 x 50mm hex socket cup screws)
  • Four M3 x 30mm hex socket cup screws
  • Four M3 x 16mm hex socket cup screws
  • Two M3 x 12mm hex socket cup screws
  • One M3 x 12mm screw
  • Four self-locking M3 nuts

Update 16-Dec-2017 Uploaded STEP file with all parts for those who wants to modify this design to fit other hotends. If you do such modification please share it with others via Remix It section.

Printer:

VERTEX K8400 with E3D print-heads

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 and 0.2

Infill:

20% and 50%

Notes:
  • Print main.stl with 0.2mm resolution, 20% infill, brim and touchbed support. Main thing needs to be printed as provided in STL file - with 15 degree angle to printbed.
  • Print holder.stl with 0.1mm resolution, 50% infill, brim and no support. holder.stl contains support pieces that need to be removed after printing.
  • Print side_holders.stl and fan_mount with 0.1mm resolution, 50% infill, no brim and no support.
  • Print duct.stl and wire_holder.stl with 0.2mm resolution, 20% infill, brim and no support. Top_cover contains fillers in all openings that are easier to remove after printing rather than cut off the brim.
  • Print top_cover.stl with 0.2mm resolution, 20% infill, no brim and no support. To improve adhesion while not filling up all the small holes this thing has, you can emulate outside-only brim by changing skirt settings in Cura to Skirt Line Count = 20 and Skirt Distance = 0.05 mm
  • Print 2 copies of lens.stl with 0.1mm resolution, 50% infill, brim and no support. Use transparent (natural) filament as the purpose of this thing is to let LED light through. You don't need this piece if you print entire top_cover with transparent filament.

My previous revision of E3D print-head contains very detailed Assembly Instructions most of which still apply. Please read them as here I will mention only whatever is new and/or different.

  • Disassemble original print-head, remove top XY CARRIAGE and install Main thing instead.
  • Place M3 nuts into Holder thing and slide it into Main thing. Slide four M3x50mm screws from the bottom up and tighten remaining 2 carriages, main thing and holder together.
  • Place hot ends between Holder and Side_holder pieces. Slide the wires into the channels of Main thing. Use M4 x16mm screws to fix hotends in position. Vertical adjustment may be required if you have 2 hotends.
  • Place the fan to the top of Main thing and place Fan_mount thing on top of the fan. Fix them in this position with four M3 x 30mm socket cup screws.
  • Replace the resistor on printed board with 33 Omh 1W resistor.
  • Place the printed board on top of Fan_mount and temporarily fix it in this position with M3 screws.
  • Connect all the wires to the printed board. Keep wires short, but don't stretch them. Wrap electrical tape around the fan and the wires (see images).
  • If Top_cover was printed in black or other non-translucent filament, glue the Lens things to the side holes of the Top_cover. Wider side of the Lens should be on outside. One drop of glue applied from inside will be enough.
  • Use two M3 x 12mm socket cup screws to attach Wire_holder to Top_cover.
  • Place Top_cover over the printed board. Use four M3 x 16mm screws to attached them both to Fan_mount.
  • Plug in the cable and use nylon wire tie to attach it to Wire_holder.
  • Attach Duct thing and fix it in position with M3 x 12mm screw.

This design allows you to gain about 4 additional millimeters of print space by Y axis and 4 by X axis. However, to get that extra space you will need to shorten the leg of XY linear bearing clamps and also update printer firmware and Repetier settings. I personally decided that the gain does not worth efforts.

comments.text: Great video, Jim!! Thanks for sharing my design. Just couple of comments:
comments.author: jimconner

comments.text: Hi Boris - I was having trouble with build plate adhesion with the fan always running at a full 12V, so I've worked out a tweak. The fan output on the main board is switched by a transistor which connects the negative side of the fan to GND. I've added 136 ohms of resistance across that transistor to ensure that the fan can never be fully switched off, and instead runs at a pre-set minimal speed whenever the printer is on (hopefully enough to keep the heatsinks cool). I used 2x 68ohm 3 watt resistors in series for the job - this gives me a minimum fan current of 72mA and fan voltage of around 3V, which is just enough for my fan to start spinning by itself and provides some gentle airflow across the heatsinks This little tweak restores full software control of the fan once again, meaning that you can have nearly no fan running for the first layer, but still ramp it up for other layers. With the fan at it's minimal speed and the extruder at 210C, I'm now measuring a steady 40C at the fin one-up from the bottom one on the heatsink - I feel that should be good enough to stop heat from the extruder making it's way back up the filament and causing clogs if I stop a print or reset the printer, and the fan will be running far faster during normal printing, cooling the heatsinks further. This tweak has massively helped with buildplate adhesion for me - I think you might like it too. Cheers!!!

comments.text: Looking at various options to mounting 2x E3D V6's on this printer.. How do you adjust the two nozzle heights so they are both exactly equal? That is currently the biggest pain in the backside with the existing K8400 hotend design!
comments.author: moojuiceuk

comments.text: That's easy. Holder and side_holder things allow to slightly move hotends up and down when screws are not tightened. Fix one hotend in a middle position (vertically) and keep screws of another loose. Level the bed against the fixed nozzle. Then push the 2nd nozzle down to align with the 1st. Finally tighten the screws of the 2nd nozzle.
comments.author: moojuiceuk

comments.text: Thank you for this design and your helpful hints. Have made one for myself and I'm quite impressed with the design so far. My only critisism is the part cooling duct at the front. Even with the best 40x40 fan I could obtain, the air pressure is not enough to be that noticable to keep PLA parts cool whilst printing, so I have stuck to using two fans, one for the heatsinks and the other for part cooling.
comments.author: Bo_Ris

comments.text: Thanks for sharing your experience and thermal images. In my case one 12V 0.24A fan works just fine (based on printout quality). I'd still like to learn what is the recommended air pressure and how narrow air stream hitting nozzle compares to the air blowing all over the place.
comments.author: moojuiceuk

comments.text: Whilst I don't think there is a right and wrong answer to part cooling, what I have found in the past is that the small fan blowing air everywhere approach does help cool the part, but also cools the hot end unless it is insulated. On the stock K8400 hotend setup I used Kapton tape around the hot end heater blocks to insulate them from the breeze from the part cooling fan. With the new E3D hotends, Im using the little silicone boots to help insulate them from that breeze. I'll probably make a duct for the small part cooling fan, to see if focusing a stronger blast of air on the part helps.

title: E3D Titan Extruder for Sintron i3

description.text:
My i3 is kind of a nightmare hybrid, with the X gantry taken from Sintron i3 patterns.

Changes from GyroBot's design:

  • Moved the belt clamp features and belt pass-through so they were in the same plane as my idler bearings and spindle. I thickened the back of the carriage by 3mm, and subtracted 3mm from the fan.
  • Since I'm using 5x10x4 idler bearings on my X axis and a 20-tooth 2GT pinion, I moved the belt pass-through channel a little bit to avoid rubbing.
  • Pulled the fan mount holes all the way through and added hexes for nuts. I didn't end up needing them, but they're nice to have just-in-case.
  • Added a central splitter in the fan duct. The printer I was using does not do bridging well, and adding this splitter made it easier to print without supports.

Due to limitations with the laser cutter I'm using, and to cut costs and trim waste, I resized the tabs to fit 1/8" plywood and laid out the parts to fit within 11x18" plywood sheets. All required parts will print, hopefully with no duplicates, if you do the following:
Page 1: Print 1x
Page 2: Print 1x
Page 3: Print 5x
Page 4: Print 2x
Page 5: Print 2x
Page 6: Print 1x
Page 7: Print 1x
Page 3 is the drawer frame. It is the same for both drawer types, just remove the center barrier for the wide drawers.
Pages 4 and 5 are the drawers themselves. Change the quantities printed according to your needs. Page 4 is a wide drawer and a narrow drawer, Page 5 is two narrow drawers, plus dividers.

title: Eleduino Raspberry Pi rainbow case stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I liked and used rewsiffer's raspberry pi upgright mount; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1263396. I used it to mount my Raspberry Pi (with a case) to the back of my dresser. You can look at the "made" section on this page to see how I use it.

I have a "rainbow" case from eleduino (http://www.eleduino.com/Rainbow-Case-for-Raspberry-pi-3-model-B-and-Raspberry-pi-2-model-B-Development-Board-p10428.html) that I wanted to put in my other Raspberry Pi. The problem is the screws for the case do not go through the Raspberry Pi mounting holes but around the outside of the case. I had to design a new mounting bracket to allow me to use the case. I wanted to use my case so I would not have the raw circuit board exposed.

I guess this is not a true remix of a part since I only used his model as a reference. I did not actually modify his design.

I wanted to be able to screw the M3 bolts into the base and not force them in. If you use a M3 tap you will be able to create threads in the holes. That way you will be able to screw / unscrew the bolts easily. I also created a countersink for the two holes to mount the stand to a surface. That way the heads of the drywall screws sit more flush with the stand.

Filament is Hatchbox's Purple:
https://www.amazon.com/HATCHBOX-3D-PLA-1KG1-75-PUR-Filament-Dimensional/dp/B00MEZDRPO/ref=sr_1_15?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1492725225&sr=1-15&keywords=hatchbox+pla+1.75

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 v 2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

To have the M3 bolts (the ones that hold the case to the unit) screw into the stand you need a M3 tap. I have designed the stand off holes to be 2.5mm so the tap will create good threads. I used M3 x 25mm long bolts to hold the case to the stand. Also, two drywall screws to mount the stand to a surface.

I used Fusion 360 and rewsiffer's desgin (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1263396) as a base to create a new stand for the eleduino rainbow case (http://www.eleduino.com/Rainbow-Case-for-Raspberry-pi-3-model-B-and-Raspberry-pi-2-model-B-Development-Board-p10428.html).

description.text: sheep head

This was designed for a pottery "slip bucket" made from a 5 gallon "paint" bucket and used for waste water during pottery throwing. The clay (now "slip") settles to the bottom, and you can open the spigot and drain off the water at the top. Beer fermenters could use this on their fermenting tanks to drain off the beer at the bottom, (Note: You'd want to print in PET and use either a gasket or food grade adhesive. But since these can be purchased for $4 on the internet, I am not sure it's worth it.)

Purchase a 5 Gallon paint bucket and a 3/4" spigot at your big box hardware store. I used E6000 as an adhesive.

Printer:

FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3 AL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35mm Layer Height

Infill:

25 %

Notes:

Inside and locking ring pieces rotate Y=90
Outside piece rotate Y=270

1. The locking ring will need a little cleanup to open the threads on the edges.
  2. Drill a 15/16" hole at your desired location in the bucket (3" from the bottom for me). Dry fit all the pieces. Having to turn the inside piece to get past the threads is ok.
  3. Put glue on the curved surface of the inside piece, ensuring that there is sufficient glue where the piece passes through bucket. Insert the piece through the hole as shown in the pictures (the long edge will be parallel to the rim of the bucket). Avoid getting glue on the threads.
  4. Put glue on the curved surface of the outside piece and slide it over the inside piece. Avoid getting glue on the threads.
  5. Screw on the locking ring and make sure everything is positioned correctly. I added a bead of glue on the inside edges, inside the bucket.
  6. Allow glue to cure.
  7. Glue the spigot to the inside piece. I used standard PVC cement for this.

print_settings.Notes:: Some Teachers wanted all 3 models on the same piece while others wanted the three models to be free-standing.  I went in after the students and added a base for those teachers who wanted them.

title: The Three States of Matter: Molecules - Solid, Liquid, and Gas

description.text: Students learned all about the three states of matter. Learning about matter the students need to identify the basic types of molecules: solid, liquid, and gas. The students learned about the size, spacing, and movement of these states of matter and needed to demonstrate their knowledge by creating a model of each. Students needed to make 3 models total. They needed to show that they understood how each of the molecules reacted and moved around each other.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Some Teachers wanted all 3 models on the same piece while others wanted the three models to be free-standing. I went in after the students and added a base for those teachers who wanted them.
CCSS

Overview Students learned all about the three states of matter. Learning about matter the students need to identify the basic types of molecules: solid, liquid, and gas. The students learned about the size, spacing, and movement of these states of matter and needed to demonstrate their knowledge by creating a model of each. Students needed to make 3 models total. They needed to show that they understood how each of the molecules reacted and moved around each other. ○ Skills Learned (Standards):
Virginia Standard SOL 3.3
The student will investigate and understand that objects are made of materials that can be described by their physical properties. Key concepts include...
a) objects are made of one or more materials;
b) materials are composed of parts that are too small to be seen without magnification; and
c) physical properties remain the same as the material is reduced in size. Common Core Standards: 3.P.2.1 & 3.P.2.1: Physical Science: Matter: Properties and Change:
Understand the structure and properties of matter before and after they undergo a change. Compare solids, liquids, and gases based on their basic properties.

Lesson Steps
  • In class students learn about different phases of matter and the behavior of molecules in those states.
  • Students are introduced to TinkerCAD and given their challenge: create a model for each state of matter: solid, liquid, and gas.
  • Then students create a drawn draft of what they want to create. Students need to make sure their molecules are the correct shape as well as spacing between each other.
  • After the student’s draft is approved by the teacher they may begin working in TinkerCAD.
  • Students log into TinkerCAD and begin creating their models of the three types of matter.
  • Once students finish the teacher needs to ensure that the creation has all of the components and is ready for printing.
  • The students take their models for one week and create their video diary showing where they see the three states of matter in the real world. (Student take pictures of the different states of matter with their molecules in the picture.)
    • We used the handout from: https://www.superteacherworksheets.com/matter/matter-article_WMTBN.pdf?up=1466611200

For this project we used:
-the handouts from the links attached
-filament for the printer
-iPads for the video diary

• 3D Creation
  • 3D Modeling
  • Molecules
  • Matter
After students learned about the States of Matter unit in class the actual 3D modeling and creating part took the students about 45-minutes in the computer lab.
Before beginning in TinkerCAD students need to understand what the different states of matter molecules look like.  They need to understand how the molecules interact and work.

By the end of the project students should have designed three models.  They should have a solid, liquid, and gas representation. They should be able to explain how the three states of matter make their molecules interact as well as a video diary of examples.

title: Pi Zero W Case + Camera mount for Replicator 1 / FlashForge Creator Pro / PowerSpec

description.text:
With the new Raspberry Pi Zero W (Pi0W) having been released, I decided to design a case and camera mount for my 3D printers. And what a better day to release it than Pi Day 2017! This should work if you don't have the front acrylic panel attached. I've included a blank top as well as one made just for the Pi Zero W. It has a little Wifi symbol over the antenna. How else are people supposed to know you've got the new Pi0W if it's in a case?

If you're printing just the case top and the bottom without the mounts (Pi_Zero_Case_Bottom_no_mount.stl & either top file), they're 33.2mm wide which means they should be just small enough to be ditto printed!

Recommended:
PLA at .2mm. Except the swivel file which should be printed at .1mm

EDIT 4: Redesigned the camera model.

  • No longer based on 3dkarma's Raspberry Pi Camera Mount with Ball Joint for Reprap. Shout out for inspiration though.
  • Started from scratch, designed the camera case. It is a snug as snug can be, you will have to pop your camera into place. If you need to get it out, gently push back on the lens area.
  • Features a swivel mount that screws into the camera arm, and allows the camera to rotate. When moving it, make sure to firmly hold the back so it doesn't pop off.

EDIT 3: Reworked then model again, again.

  • Moved microSD opening, camera opening, HDMI openings. Not a huge huge change if you had the last revision. But this is just a cleaner better aligned design.
  • Moved camera hinges on case bottom to be a little bit higher for a better view. Still trying to figure out a way to adjust the camera tilt.

EDIT 2: Reworked the model again.

  • Walls are about the same thickness, though I made the actual hole your Pi Zero fits into tighter. It should be an exact fit and not move. It may be snug, but it fits if you pop it down. PLEASE COMMENT IF YOU'RE HAVING ISSUES WITH IT BEING TOO TIGHT.
  • Reworked the top plate to fit into the newer size of the bottom.
  • I found the ball and socket attachments weren't strong enough to keep the camera in place with the weight + tension from the cable. Replaced with hinges that require screws. I'm using screws and nuts that were included in my "replacement parts" for my machine.

EDIT: Reworked the model.

  • Made the outside walls slighty thinner for better cable connection to their ports (mini HDMI). Both parts of the case are now 1mm thinner.
  • Also reworked the top piece to fit inside the bottom better and not fall off.
  • Widened the microSD hole for easier access, also added to the top plate to help fill empty space above the microSD slot so you don't accidentally put it there.
  • Redesigned the camera attaching area. Still working on that part.
  • I added just the case bottom with no mounts for other projects.

Printer Brand:

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

I recommend PLA. Everything can be printed at .2mm layer height except for Pi_Zero_Case_Camera_Swivel.stl which must be printed at .1mm height for best results.

comments.text: Love it, thanks! If you're trying to get the camera to tilt, maybe try a ball/socket joint, similar to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247590?

description.text:
This is based on my 9MM, 45 ACP, 40 S&W boxes which can be found here. I wanted boxes for my .223 reloading so this box is designed with the same foot print at the other boxes but taller. It uses the same lid as the other boxes. There are two main versions, a 50 round box and a 60 round box. I decided to go with 50 because it allowed me to have groups of 10 rounds which I find very useful for tuning my reloads. I make 10 rounds of each spec and then test them to determine which reload specs are best for each of my rifles. The 10 round groups make it easy to document which loads I'm testing. Please message me if you think 60 rounds/box would be better. I'm still undecided. Going with 50 for now. I'd be happy to create a 60 round version if people think that would be better.

Based on feedback I've added .stl files for .223 and 5.56x45. I haven't printed the 5.56 box yet, but it looks like the txt fits ok. Message me if it doesn't

If you are looking for Pistol boxes, check out my matching pistol boxes here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1559655 You will also find some addition printing instructions there.

Have fun with this box. Let me know if you like it, or have any suggestions. Having said that, if you are going to nit-pick my wording of things, please don't bother. Looking for constructive feedback only.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20% for the box, 100% for the lid

Notes:

I used Hatchbox PLA at 210deg or eSun PLApro at 225deg

Both work good.

Post Processing

Cut the built in support from the lid's latch with a exact knife.
Clean out the holes on the BOX with a small drill bit that's approx the size of the hole.
Use #16 x 1.5" Smooth Shank Wire Nails as your hinges. You'll need to snip them off to the length of the combined hinges so they don't poke out. Makes a very nice smooth pivot which doesn't work itself out and lasts a long time.

author: vegos

title: Diameter Calibration for Holes and Cylinders (2,0-3,9 _ 0,1Steps) (updated)

description.text:
this is basically a small plate with different cylinders ( =outer diameters) and holes ( =inner diameters) from 2,0mm-3,9mm increasing by 0,1mm steps

had lots of trouble in the past with tolerances and now i know why... my printer is off.
i messured the print, did some excel-magic and BOOM:
the maximum differences are from +0,1mm to -0,44mm
(see the graphs: the closer the line is to the blue one, the better)

right now i know HOW MUCH it is off, but not HOW to FIX the issue. (see my printer settings below)

maybe this is a hint: to roughly fit the messurements of a model (the 20mm calibration cube for example) i constantly have to scale them up for ~2% - but only in the x&y axes...

suggestions are welcome!!

=========================================

[update 30.03.2017]
first of all: thanks for the many suggestions, you came up with!!

1) check stepper-driver voltage (by shooter40000)
if the motors don't get enough energy, the magnets can't hold the correct position.
so things like layer-shifting appears
--> didn't help, because i already did this months ago :-)
--> but it's RECOMMENDED TO CHECK THIS OUT!

2) material's shrinkage (J741)
as the warm plastic gets cold, it shrinks. especially ABS is very well known for its warping "qualities"
--> common issue with 3d printing

3) check the stepper motor's "steps per mm" in the firmware (by Solarenemy and J741)
[see the pic "2nd try"]
the printer has to be told, how long the distance of one step is, it's stepper motors actually do.
--> well, i didn't got rid of the problem, but it helped to get more even results (0,0 to -0,26mm). and from now on i don't have to increase the models in my slicer to x&y=102% anymore.
--> So IT ACTUALLY HELPED!! :-)
for a HOW-TO, check out

  • Kossel / Delta Dimensional Calibration with Instructions (by Coffea)(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2201324)
  • my Make with instructions for a non-delta printer with Marlin firmware
    (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:319801)

4) try slower printing speed (by Plust)
[see the pic "3rd try"]
to increase the details on your prints, it's good to go slow.
the printer is more accurate, and the plastic has more time to cool down = the 2nd layer doesn't melt the 1st layer.
--> the difference between normal speed (2nd try) and half speed is interesting:

  • the inner diameter got worse at the <3,0mm holes. but above it got closer and even matched the design parameters two times (3,5mm & 3,8mm)!
  • the outer diameter got improved by an average 0,05mm.
    --> definitely worth a try!!

5) it's the polygons fault (by chantling and Scabby)
3D-models are made out of many little triangles. so every round shape differs to it's original. this is why we need to consider tolerances up to 0,5mm while designing for FDM-printing. and the smaller it gets, the more difficult it becomes.
--> common issue with 3d printing
--> chantling provided two informative links in the comment section, check them out!

The Replicator Makerbot Arms are awesome, but they're a bit big for the Thing-O-Matic.
I scaled them down to 75%, merged the parts for single-extruder printing and modified the mount for more flexible positioning. (I mounted them onto my Gen 4 Interface)

Print two of each part. Snap together. Apply your choice of fixing agent to flat side of mounting plate (Sugru, Double-Stick Foam, Velcro or Glue) (Note: Barsoomian Bots will require four of each part, Octo-Bots will need 8) For Jetty firmware users wanting multi-colored prints, set the following Z pauses: 10.46mm all three parts for the contrasting color
14.22mm for Hand and Arm screw/plate detail
18.4mm for Shoulder logo

This is an original creation that I made for a class. The holder is designed to hold a small case, such as a Xbox One or a PS4 game case. I was able to get a bigger printer so I made the case holder better. All you need to do is glue the support to the holder and place the support into the base and it should be able to revolve.

Update: I made the holder a little bit less bulky in order to use less filament and make it print fast.

Folgertech FT-5 Custom Parts

This is a collection of custom designed parts I have created to replace parts on my Folgertech FT-5; most were modifications on the existing parts that I created using SketchUp.

  • Y-motor and y-pulley mounts
    • Replace parts FT-17 and FT-18
    • Designed to be ambidextrous
  • Chain attachment
    • Provides a mount point for the y-axis cable chain
  • Surface braces
    • Replace the paper clasps and are fully custom designed
    • Installed by replacing 3 of the surface leveling screws by:
      • Reverse the screw, placing the brace on it, then the spring and finally the thumb screw

All parts are designed to attach with the pre-existing screws/t-nuts or spare parts left over from the initial build.

title: Boardgame character stat markers and holder for Betrayal at House on the Hill

description.text: The excellent boardgame Betrayal at House on the Hill has markers for the character boards that keep slipping off, so while playing with friends, I thought I would try to improve how that works with a clip over stats holder.

Print in ABS or PLA, try and make you first layer a good one, as the print is used upside-down so that will be your 'customer facing' layer. I only had a couple of cards to play with, and there was quite a bit of difference in the print to cut registration, so I can see this might not line up well with your cards - let me know how it fits and please post pictures of your prints!

comments.text: Any advice on what settings to use when printing? I'm trying to print it using PLA 190º extruder and 60º heating bed. I'm experiencing a lot of warping, any advice will help.
comments.author: melianguidry

comments.text:
Don't heat your bed for PLA, try a slightly hotter PLA temp, use fresh painters tape and make sure your bed is aligned to print a good 1st layer.
For ABS, you may have trouble printing such a large piece due to the print shrinking, hot box your printer and print at maybe 103% to allow for the contraction when it cools. Good luck and welcome to 3D printing!

description.text:
Included STLs are for 4mm allen centre hole and M8 nuts (or no nuts). Height is 8 mm and tolerance is at 0.15. Adjust accordingly for your printer tolerances and preferences. The nuts are not necessary but more mass means more spinning. If you decide not to use nuts, you may want to print it with more infil.

Open 'bearing-spinner.scad' to make changes. The SCAD file can take a while to render.

Video here: https://youtu.be/KZcjZevxDyo

Attributions:
  • Gear Bearing by emmett
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451
  • smooth spinner openscad by bda
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2112021
  • nutsnbolts by JohK
    https://github.com/JohK/nutsnbolts

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%+

As with emmett's geared bearing, you will have to break it in by spinning it. The included STLs will work fine with a 4mm allen. If you printed cutouts for nuts, it's helpful if you put your nuts in the freezer first, put a bolt into them and smash them in with a hammer.

comments.text: everytime i print this the gears get fused and i cannot get them unstuck what should i do? (0.4 mm nozzle)
comments.author: KidsAlex

comments.text: Assuming you've made no changes to the STL, put a 4mm allen wrench into it and turn it side to side. You should slowly start to get more play and eventually it will break free. If your gears are truly fused, then the model will break or the hex hole will deform before the gears start turning. In that case, it could be that the tolerances are too tight for your printer.
comments.author: KidsAlex

comments.text: okay thank you, i tried slowly wiggling them free, but it just stripped the hole so i will use openscad
comments.author: fumbucker

comments.text: If you are familiar with OpenSCAD, you might want to try printing just the bearing and see if it works. That way you'll save a bit of material if it fails. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451

title: Rock / Print Tumbler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my rendition of a simple rock tumbler. Inspired by onkelgeorg's Affordable Rock Tumbler. The following axle can be located in one of several positions to accommodate a wider variety of tumbler sizes. I have been using an empty paint can with a few ribs glued inside to encourage tumbling. Wrapping the can with some grippy draw liner material keeps the can from slipping on the tumbler's rollers. While I scavanged rollers from an old printer/scanner/fax machine to attach to the axels, I have included some that can be printed out. Included are one flat roller and one with an extra lip on one end to keep your tumbler from walking from one side or the other while spinning.

This is a sturdy tumbler. I have been using it for several weeks now with no issues or sign of excessive wear. I have tumbled as much as 5 lbs. of material with no sign of fatigue or strain from the drivetrain.

Hardware

  • (1) 158mm/79 tooth GT2 belt
  • (4) 608 bearings
  • (4) M3 12mm hex cap screws
  • (2) M3 nuts
  • (2) M3 washers
  • (8) M6 25mm bolts
  • (8) M6 nylon lock nuts
  • (18) M8 nuts
  • (4) M8 washers
  • (1) M8 215mm threaded rod
  • (1) M8 235mm threaded rod
  • (1) 12V DC 0.5A(500mA) Power Supply
  • (1) 12V DC 100RPM motor/gearbox with centric output shaft
  • (1) SPST Toggle Switch (optional)
  • (1) 2.1 x 5.5mm DC Female Power Plug Pigtail Cable (optional)
  • (4-6) Adhesive Rubber Feet Pads (keeps your tumbler from walking around while its running)

comments.text: Do you know if the gears from the original design will fit with your spacing?

comments.text: i have not tried it, but they should fit. I believe there is enough slip in the motor mount to account for the gears.

comments.text:
Hi there, awesome looking tumbler would like to print and build but my electronics skills are poor, would there be any chance in wiring schematic?
Thanks
comments.author: ch33123

comments.text:
It's simple.
Negative from the power supply goes to the motor.
Positive from the power supply goes to the normally open toggle switch
The other normally open part of the toggle switch goes to the other lead on the motor.

I break my glasses frames a lot, they are currently almost half made of glue and varying adhesion products. I designed these so I could just print out new frames or frame pieces whenever I needed to, they are shaped so I can simply pop in my current lenses. These are a work in progress, and now that I have a CAD model of my own glasses I can add space for surface mount electronics, wires, and such.
To make them I taped my current frames to my screen zoomed to a 1:1 ratio, and carefully made a spline of the lens perimeter dimension, then did a bunch of fine tuning with my calipers and the dots consisting of the spline. All the other splines were done visually to my taste, as long as the lens dimensions are good the rest of the glasses can be any shape.
I haven't printed these out yet, but when I do this is my plan. I am going to use a hot air reflow station to heat up the nose bridge and lens areas, then bend them to the same curvature of my current frames by just holding the two parallel to each other. I designed the frames to be just a little bit smaller than in real life to try and accommodate for the geometric stretching they will experience.
To make sure your lenses will fit in the frames print the image out at a 1:1 scale and cut out the interior of the frames, then insert the pieces of paper into your current frames and adjust accordingly.
If your first pair doesn't ft the way you wanted, measure the improper dimensions, update your model, and reprint!
Take heed in the work-in-progress sign. The hinges may need to be beefed, up; I have multiple files ready to go so stay tuned.
If you want the CAD documents for these files give YouMagine some love at https://www.youmagine.com/designs/glasses-frames#!design-information Detailed information here: http://umforum.ultimaker.com/index.php?/topic/3932-designing-a-new-set-of-glasses-frames/?p=57088

title: SNOOD for laser head of 43mm diameter.  (as from OptLasers. Poland)

description.text:
Makerspace Guernsey just purchased a 5W diode laser module for building into a CNC engraver/cutter. We chose the CLH-5000 from OptLasers, Poland, and purchased through eBay.

It's a fine piece of kit but of course it will benefit from some air cooling, air flow over the lens and air-assist for better cutting — so here it is.

We've printed it in clear PLA and coloured the front of the snood in fluorescent yellow highlighter pen so the when the (near UV) laser is firing the front cone lights up brightly.    ;)

• The cone forms the main body and brings the airflow down to a fairly fine jet.
• The vanes draw the airflow over the lens and support the front of the laser head.
• The back flange centres the cone body on the laser head.

It's designed to accept regular 4/6mm aquarium air hose.

Some light sanding may be required for part fitting.

Español

Aprovechando el generador de bandejas que subí previamente he creado un sistema apilable y personalizable que permite usar cualquier envase como contenedor de las bandejas y poder extraerlas fácilmente al disponer de una pestaña para poder levantarlas todas a la vez.

Es una manera de aprovechar los tuppers que tenemos sin uso pero que podemos usarlos para guardar cosas pequeñas en ellos aunque en realidad pueden generarse bandejas para cualquier contenedor.

He puesto 3 ejemplos (pero no se limita a estos usos):

  • Gaveta extraible de un gavetero de Lidl
  • Bandejas para aprovechar una caja de SMINT.
  • Tupper pequeño con partes desordenadas y mezcladas.
Uso

Descomprimir el archivo StackableBoxSystem.zip y abrir con OpenSCAD el archivo StackableBoxSystem.scad.

El código está bastante comentado, pero básicamente las variables a modificar son:

  • width: Ancho del contenedor de las cajas (eje X).
  • length: Largo del contenedor de las cajas (eje Y).
  • height: Alto del contenedor de las cajas (eje Z).
  • thickness: Grosor de las paredes.
  • tolerance: Tolerancia a usar para que el pin entre en las ranuras.
  • cells: Configuración de las celdas de cada caja. Cada celda tiene 2 valores (ver http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152853), el número de divisiones en el eje X y el número de divisiones en el eje Y.
  • pinSize: Radio del pin a usar para poder levantar todas las cajas o ancho en caso de ser rectangular.
  • radius: Radio de los bordes (ver http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152853).
  • only: Índice del elemento que se quiere mostrar o -1 para mostrar todos. Es útil para cuando se quiere imprimir solamente una parte.
Enlace

https://gitlab.com/joaquinfq/openscad/blob/master/Modules/Storage/StackableBoxSystem.scad

English

Taking advantage of the generator of trays that I uploaded previously I have created a stackable and customizable system that allows to use any container for the trays and to be able to extract them easily with a flap to be able to lift them all at the same time.

It is a way to take advantage of the tuppers that we have without use but we can use them to keep small things but really it can be to generate trays for any container.

I have put 3 examples (but are not limited to these uses):

  • Drawer for a Powerfix (Lidl) cabinet.
  • Trays to take advantage of a SMINT box.
  • Small Tupper with unsorted and mixed parts.
Usage

Uncompress the file StackableBoxSystem.zip and open StackableBoxSystem.scad.

The code is quite commented, but basically the variables to be modified are:

  • width: Container width (X axis).
  • length: Container length (Y-axis).
  • height: Container height (Z axis).
  • thickness: Thickness of walls.
  • tolerance: Tolerance to use for the pin to enter the slots.
  • cells: Configuration of the cells of each box. Each cell has 2 values (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152853), the number of divisions on the X axis, and the number of divisions on the Y axis.
  • pinSize: Pin radius to use to be able to lift all boxes or width in case of being rectangular.
  • radius: Radius of each corner (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2152853).
  • only: Index of the item to display or -1 to show all. It is useful when you want to print only one part.
Link

https://gitlab.com/joaquinfq/openscad/blob/master/Modules/Storage/StackableBoxSystem.scad

title: Nylon Ring for Yamaha Raptor One-Way Bearing

description.text:
this did fail shortly after the last update, but i have recently found why it failed. turns out the individual bearing pieces were ground down so much, they created a razor sharp edge inside the grove this/the spring mounts, thus quickly slicing anything you put in there to pieces.
it probably would have lasted a very long time if i wasn't for the razor sharp parts.
i've since gotten a good deal on some 031 o-rings (1-3/4"ID, 1-7/8"OD), and am using 2x of those now that i have fixed the razor sharp parts.

Update 3-16-17: this ring has been working wonderfully so far, no signs of stretching or breakage, sounds completely normal when starting/stopping.

doubt anybody will ever find or download this, but here it is, a very simple ring meant to be printed in weed wacker/weedeater nylon trimmer line.
this replaces the metal spring that tensions the one-way bearing parts.
with the yamaha raptor, at least mine, a 2001, it had a major tendency to spin the crank backwards during a backfire, or failed attempt at starting, etc., which results in the one-way bearing parts expanding a ton, thus breaking the spring.
i have been using plain old very-low tension rubber bands, and they last for a few months.
got tired of replacing the rubber-bands, so i'm gonna try this. (btw, buying the part is very expensive, thus making a printed part really wonderful)

the best way to install this, that i have found, is take the one way out and remove the top lipped retainer, remove all the bearings, note the direction of the vertical line, then take either all or 3/4 of the bearings, and slide them onto the ring, then slide the assy back onto the main part, similar to the first pic, then slightly stretch the ring, and insert individual bearings until you are done, then re-assy and put it back in the engine and have fun!
end product should look like pic 2.

title: Ikea Fräck Mic Stand for MXL Microphone

description.text:
I wanted to wall-mount my MXL USB 006 microphone, and I wanted a scissor arm to do it!

I found the Ikea Fräck mirror's arm to be perfect, cost $10.

Three revisions in, I'm happy enough to stop revising.

The interior of the mic's mount is just a model of the mic itself, subtracted from the mic stand. Modifying this to work with other microphones would be mostly a matter of modeling your microphone in openscad, and hacking it in place ;)

Keeping the version controlled copy on github here:
https://github.com/flyswatter/ikea-accordion-mic-stand

title: Semi circular fan duct for Tech2C E3D V6 X-carriage

description.text:
Update 28.3.2017: - Added a by 2mm reduced version which should fit the original E3D V6 also.
Distance between center screwholes and top is still the same. Cut was made within the lower part.

So this is my very first "New thing"..i am always open for criticism, so fell free

I printed Tech2C´s "E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount v2 for Prusa i3" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847) which is great, but the fan duct is blowing onto the Nozzle (E3D clone with peaking M7 thread, so it is longer than the original one) and that, in some cases, caused the filament to cool down within the noozle at times when the fan was above 60%.
And i wanted to adapt the semi circular fan duct (used this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1954001) to this setup.
So i combined both, the integrated Tech2C fanduct with the semi circular end made by lokster and others.

As sensor mount i recommend this with a 10mm offset http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1639085

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Made two slightly different versions.

No1.: print with support if your slicer can manage that correctly. As a student i can not afford Simplify3D, so it is kind of difficult to set the support for the wanted positions.

No2.: printable without support. The "wings" for the screws are a little benchmark in terms of overhang.

So, the version to print depends on the used slicer...i would say

Attention!!

This version was originally made for the about 1-1.5 mm longer E3D V6 clone. This will fit the original one too. But comes close to the bed if ur noozle hight isn´t adjusted perfectly.

print_settings.Notes:: The hopper and lid assembly has a lot of support material to remove, and the skittles can jam, depending on the bottle you are using.  I will try to solve the jamming problem by adding a skewed funnel so that two skittles cannot enter the column at the same time!

description.text:
I designed a skittle dispenser that works with a 9g servo. The hopper has a thread that accepts most soft drink bottles, which you would empty, dry and fill with skittles. This was linked to a times table tester(https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/148375859/) , and a Year 5 / Year 6 spelling tester made in Scratch for my kids. After a set number of random questions, the servo spits out a tasty reward. This was designed in tinkercad, and adapted from original project https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:379273 (thanks to @Kumy).

My children have since learnt their times tables with far less grumbling, and even non standard times tables, like the 7.4 times table!

This could be used as a part of a more complicated skittle sorting mechanism that I haven't yet made!

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

CEL Robox

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal: 0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The hopper and lid assembly has a lot of support material to remove, and the skittles can jam, depending on the bottle you are using. I will try to solve the jamming problem by adding a skewed funnel so that two skittles cannot enter the column at the same time!

BOM:
A plastic drinks bottle with a threaded lid: Most pop or soda bottles will work - £1, or get out of the recycling bin
9g micro servo - £3 from ebay
skittles - £1 per pack. Any other flattened spherical sweets might also work.
raspberry pi zero £5.

I designed this project around the bottle as a hopper, and the servo as the mechanism. I tried to limit the amount of movement the servo would make to relieve physical stress, and I made the tolerances so that two skittles could never fit inside the mechanism at once and jam up the servo. At the moment, the two halves are simply taped together, but when I have this working perfectly, I will glue/screw the two halves together.

This is my mounting solution for the MPCNC and the DeWalt DWP611 Spindle.

NOTE: 25.4mm Version ONLY

FEATURES:

  • Bult in vacuum ring around the tool, with nozzle spout (30mm diameter lip, make sure your hose has an inner diameter of about that much
  • Mounting holes for add-on plates: the design can be expanded by mounting accessories to the bottom using existing screw points (e.g. a dust brush, different kinds of attachments, etc)
  • One piece ToolMount: replaces the existing tool mount on the MPCNC and screws directly to the tubes
  • Holes for the lights on the DWP611 to shine through.
  • DWP611 vent air redirection: directs the air blowing out the bottom of the DPW611 to the sides of the mount, preventing it from kicking up dust or chips and letting the vacuum work.
  • Robust design securely holds tool, easy to take out and screw in.

Printing takes about 8.5 hours at 0.3mm with a base speed of 70mm/s. Let me know if you make one!

Read the full guide on: https://learn.adafruit.com/3d-printed-electronic-sunglasses/overview

In this week's project, we’ll show you how to build pair of electronic sunglasses. These are really cool because you can actually control the dark tint from the glass.

Sandwiched in between two sheets of glass is a layer of liquid crystal material. When voltage is applied to the electrodes, it turns dark and filters out bright light. Depending on how much voltage is applied, you can control the tint or opaqueness of the glass.

This is a Liquid Crystal Light Valve (a.k.a a LCD Controllable Blackout Panel) and they’re mainly used in welding helmets because it can protecting your eyes from really bright sparks.

title: Case / Enclosure for Adafruit's ESP8266 Breakout Board (Huzzah)

description.text:
Best used with male headers soldered top-side (though now available with bottom cutout too). Try using the asterisk cutout to organize if free wiring.

Printing notes

This case was designed around a 0.48mm extrusion width. This gives the features on the case a bit of added strength. If the case isn't printing quite right, try adjusting the slicer's extrusion width.

Buttons

The two buttons are held in by a toe-like lip (so if the case gets flipped upside down the buttons don't go flying everywhere(!)). To insert them, put the toe in first and press it in at an angle. Depending on your print a bit of filing or cutting may make insertion easier!

Dust covers

There are two covers to keep things somewhat clean. Both are press-fit, with the asterisk cover having a looser/thinner fit. They're optional and are included in the 'everything' plate, as well as separately.

Updates

2017-08-17: Added a case with slots for bottom side headers.

2017-03-15: Increased the size of the header cutout and made the asterisk cutout a bit sturdier.

Prusa i3 MK2

0.2mm

20%

title: Mobile Frame Zero: Shinonome SN-3 "Karasu"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"As soon as Shinonome Frame Corporation began retiring its mass-produced SN-0s and SN-1Hs from battle, it began developing a replacement, one that would not fail where its predecessors did. Within months, a new successor was born: the SN-3. The flight-capable "Karasu" is clad in a black paint job punctuated by grey, and operated by a pilot with above-average intelligence and memory, bearing likeness to its namesake. The pilot is situated in such a way that their head is contained within the frame's, with the rest of their body in the frame's chest, right above a multiple-use, single-shot rocket launcher located in the abdomen (below a single-use railgun). Many SN-3 pilots perform brutal finishers on opponents' frames, hugging them close and then using the rocket to punch a hole clean through the abdomen. On each side of the SN-3's torso are two radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTGs), which need replacing after 168 hours of use because of the frame's energy-hungry Shinonome hybrid joints. The SN-3 has a pair of back-mounted retractable machine guns with a wide range of motion. These guns search for, identify, and perforate threats independent of each other and the pilot. The SN-3 comes with not one, but two traditionally forged swords. This frame's simple yet brutal armament is a force to be reckoned with, and ensures the continuation of Shinonome Frame Corporation's dominance on the battlefield."

From left to right in LXF file: skeleton, model as built in real life, "Corvespa" reskin in action.

TIPS:
-It takes less force to break the shoulder off the model than to position it.
Model is back-heavy; position ankles forward as shown in LXF file.

Systems
Defense: Tracking Guns
Movement: Flight
Surveillance: N/A
Melee: Swords
Direct Fire: Tracking Guns
Artillery: Railgun
x3 Single-Shot Rockets

For more info on Mobile Frame Zero, a Lego-based wargame: http://mobileframezero.com/mfz/

description.text:
This is a replacement for the really bad clothes-clip like magnetic thing that Molex provides with their "0640160205 Hand Crimper Tool Rectangular Contacts, 18-30 AWG Side Entry, Ratchet" to hold the crimp connector while crimping. The crimper is really good, the magnetic adapter - meh.

So, this is a two-part device printout. The little piece slides into the large piece which is then screwed on where the old clothes-clip magnetic shelf went.

When done, there's a rectangular hole of the right depth so you can just place the crimp connector into the hole, then crimp, then remove the crimped wire. Painless.

Note that I used a 50% infill to get strength up on this thing. May not be necessary, but...

DonÂ´t know if this is the first fabber part ever, but it was mine.
In 2003 the crank of my cheese grater broke. I liked the design and was not willing to waste it. But I had no idea where to get the spare part. So I decided in my christmas holidays 2003 to build it by myself. I designed an optimized version with turnable crank grip and built it in Alumide on a laser-sintering machine. It broke never again and is still in use. I looked on the save date of the original file: it is 01.01.2004. Let me know if you know a documented case earlier.

If you like to do something similar with movable elements for laser-sintering, you should choose a gap width of 0.25 to 0.3mm. Furthermore, if possible, reduce the bearing surfaces to a minimum to ensure easy loosening of the elements and removal of loose powder. For a round axis for example you could design 3 small bearing surfaces around the axis in a distance of 120Â° instead of using just a circle-cross section.

This is a simple mount for a TBS unify. It provides space underneath to locate and mount your receiver underneath and then allows for the TBS VTX to be mounted on top. Its printed in two part to make it easier to print and also allows for some adjustment to fit in the frames. This was made specifically for the Armattan Chameleon, but would fit most other long deck frames. Overall height is 15.5mm.

For the Chameleon I used a hacksaw to cut the tabs on the Unify pigtail to it fitted into the rear VTX mount.

Once you are have the top and bottom located how you want just use some superglue to glue together. This will also strengthen the whole piece.

There are also ziptie slot to allow you to ziptie to the frame and also the TBS pigtail to reduce any stress on the UFL. All I did was turn the UFL connection 180 degrees to fit nicely in the Chameleon frame. (Refer pictures for details)

This is a functional design, and is not the prettiest, but so far has worked well. I have not fully crash tested it to see how it holds. So you at your own risk :)

remixed_from.author: Nathan_
remixed_from.title: TBS Discovery Brushless Gimbal for Hero 3

description.text:
Work in progress....

My design is using iPower Motor GBM2804 100T motors.
I had to use a step bit to clean the circular holes.

My original remix design had a flaw where I removed the hole that allowed for a bearing rod. This clamped the mount of the arm down on the bearing, locking it up in the process. I then added the hole back into the design on one end of each arm because it was only locking up one side of the motor. This hole needed a little extra space so I drilled it out. I figure the friction from the drill bit slightly melts the layers around the hole and adds more structural integrity to the fair size hole, I'd rather do this than enlarge the hole from a design standpoint.

I plan on using M3 washers on all of screws to help with pressure disbursement on the area around the mounting holes.

Base is a Work in Progress.
The entire thing is a work in progress because I am still adding features to the camera housing. After adding features to the camera housing I will then need to add or subtract a given length to one or all of the parts to accommodate for balancing the entire gimbal.

I decided to add cable managing features to the design and added more geometry to strengthen it a bit because the pieces I needed were considerably longer.

description.text: A nuclear symbol shaped fidget spinner. Enjoy!

A wonderful idea has occurred while I was browsing thingiverse.
It would take some time and effort, but what if you made a version of this design that had three spaces that fit these on the ends of the spinner, so when it was spun, it would create a green ring produced by a radioactive element, on a radioactive spinner. It would literally be a nuclear spinner.
